*: [[Islamic Consultative Assembly (Iran)|Iranian parliament speaker]] [[Ali Larijani]] said, "The voice of the brave people of Egypt is the voice of revolution. The start of this revolution has astonished the despotic regimes of the region. The parliament supports the uprising of the Tunisian and Egyptian people." He described the protests as "the revolution of the noble."<ref>{{cite web|author=Name * |url=http://www.pakistantoday.com.pk/2011/01/iran-backs-egypts-revolution-of-the-noble/ |title=Iran backs Egypt's 'revolution of the noble' | Pakistan Today | Latest news, Breaking news, Pakistan News, World news, business, sport and multimedia |publisher=Pakistan Today |date=2011-01-30 |accessdate=2011-04-27}}</ref> Iran backed the protests. Parliament speaker [[Ali Larijani]] called the uprising the "revolution of the noble". He compared Western reaction to the protests with their reaction to the 1979 [[Islamic Revolution]].<ref>{{cite news|author=[[Staff writer]]|title=Iran Backs Egypt's 'Revolution of the Noble'|publisher=''[[Agence France-Presse]]'' (via ''[[The Times of India]]'')|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/world/middle-east/Iran-backs-Egypts-revolution-of-the-noble/articleshow/7392036.cms|date=30 January 2011|accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref>

* {{flag|Canada}} â [[Canadian Foreign Affairs Minister]] [[Lawrence Cannon]] said that Egypt remains an [[Canada-Egypt relations|important partner]] for Canada and urged "the Egyptian government to ensure full freedom of political expression for its citizens." He said the Canadian government "continues to stand by the people of Egypt as they demand democratic reforms and respect for human rights. We urge the Government of Egypt to begin an immediate transition toward serious democratic reform."<ref>(2 February 2011). [http://www.international.gc.ca/media/aff/news-communiques/2011/044.aspx?lang=eng "Minister Cannon Condemns Violence in Egypt"]. Retrieved 2 February 2011.</ref>

* {{flag|United States}} â [[President of the United States|US President]] [[Barack Obama]], noting that he had spoken with the Egyptian president, stated that his first concern is preventing injury or loss of life. He remarked, "What's needed right now are concrete steps that advance the rights of the Egyptian people...Ultimately the future of Egypt will be determined by the Egyptian people. The United States will always be a committed partner to that future, with the Egyptian government, and with the Egyptian people." He recalled that in his [[A New Beginning|speech in Cairo]] in June 2009 he had stated, "All governments must maintain power through consent, not coercion," and called upon the Egyptian government to restore its people's access to the internet. He called on all parties to refrain from violence in their efforts to bring about a solution.<ref name="Barack Obama">{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/news/blog/2011/jan/28/egypt-protests-live-updates|title=Egypt Protests Live Updates|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=28 January 2011|accessdate= 28 January 2011|location=London|first1=Matthew|last1=Weaver|first2=Haroon|last2=Siddique|first3=Richard|last3=Adams|first4=Tim|last4=Hill}}</ref> He said that the Egyptian protesters have "universal" rights, including the right to peaceful assembly and association, free speech, and âthe ability to determine their own destiny. [...] These are human rights and the United States will stand up for them everywhere."<ref>Johnston, Nicholas; Brower, Kate Andersen (29 January 2011). [http://www.bloomberg.com/news/28 January 2011/obama-says-mubarak-must-take-concrete-steps-to-deliver-pledge-on-reforms.html "Obama Tells Mubarak He Must Stick to Pledge of Democratic Reforms in Egypt"]. ''[[Bloomberg]]''. Retrieved 29 January 2011.</ref> White House spokesman [[Robert Gibbs]] expressed anger at the pace of change in Egypt, saying the transition should happen quickly, which he also said would determine US aid to the country.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://washingtonexaminer.com/politics/2011/02/us-angered-over-egypt-hopeful-over-yemen-jordan |title=US angered over Egypt, hopeful over Yemen, Jordan | The Associated Press | Politics |publisher=Washington Examiner |date=2011-02-02 |accessdate=2011-04-27}}</ref> Gibbs posted a statement on [[Twitter]] expressing concern "about violence in Egypt", adding the "government must respect the rights of the Egyptian people & turn on social networking and the internet".<ref name="Twitter">{{cite web|url=http://twitter.com/PressSec/status/31026478648926208|title=Gibbs on Twitter|date=28 January 2011|accessdate= 28 January 2011}}</ref>
+

He remarked, "What's needed right now are concrete steps that advance the rights of the Egyptian people...Ultimately the future of Egypt will be determined by the Egyptian people. *: [[United States Secretary of State|US Secretary of State]] [[Hillary Clinton]] said, "The Egyptian government has an important opportunity to be responsive to the aspirations of the Egyptian people, and pursue political, economic and social reforms that can improve their lives and help Egypt prosper."<ref name="Clinton">{{cite web|author=Awad, Marwa; Dziadoszurl, Alexander|url=http://www.publicbroadcasting.net/wrni/news.newsmain/article/0/0/1754229/.World./Egypt's.Mubarak.faces.unprecedented.protests|title=Egypt's Mubarak Faces Unprecedented Protests|publisher=''[[Reuters]]'' (via ''[[WRNI]]'')|date=25 January 2011|accessdate= 31 January 2011}}</ref> She told ''Al Jazeera'' that Mubarak has been an ally of the US in the past because he has maintained the [[EgyptâIsrael Peace Treaty|peace treaty]] with Israel in maintaining stability.<!--from tv-->{{Citation needed|date=January 2011}} She said the US supports an "orderly transition."<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/2011130164532649572.html |title=''Al Jazeera'' Undeterred by Egypt Curb â Will Continue Its Comprehensive Coverage of Landmark Events There, Says Network Chief|work=[[Al Jazeera English]] |date=30 January 2011 |accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> On 8 March Clinton said Egypt's transition to democracy would be incomplete if women were not equal partners with men in creating the new society. She criticised the lack of women involved in efforts to draft a new constitution, saying in part, "The women in Egypt and [[Tunisia]] and other nations have just as much right as the men to remake their governments â to make them responsive, accountable, transparent."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/03/08/clinton-women-middle-east-international-womens-day_n_832974.html|date=8 March 2011|accessdate=9 March 2011|agency=The Huffington Post|title=Clinton: Women Must Get Role In Middle East Transition}}</ref>
*: [[United States Secretary of State|US Secretary of State]] [[Hillary Clinton]] said, "The Egyptian government has an important opportunity to be responsive to the aspirations of the Egyptian people, and pursue political, economic and social reforms that can improve their lives and help Egypt prosper."<ref name="Clinton">{{cite web|author=Awad, Marwa; Dziadoszurl, Alexander|url=http://www.publicbroadcasting.net/wrni/news.newsmain/article/0/0/1754229/.World./Egypt's.Mubarak.faces.unprecedented.protests|title=Egypt's Mubarak Faces Unprecedented Protests|publisher=''[[Reuters]]'' (via ''[[WRNI]]'')|date=25 January 2011|accessdate= 31 January 2011}}</ref> She told ''Al Jazeera'' that Mubarak has been an ally of the US in the past because he has maintained the [[EgyptâIsrael Peace Treaty|peace treaty]] with Israel in maintaining stability.<!--from tv-->{{Citation needed|date=January 2011}} She said the US supports an "orderly transition."<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/2011130164532649572.html |title=''Al Jazeera'' Undeterred by Egypt Curb â Will Continue Its Comprehensive Coverage of Landmark Events There, Says Network Chief|work=[[Al Jazeera English]] |date=30 January 2011 |accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> On 8 March Clinton said Egypt's transition to democracy would be incomplete if women were not equal partners with men in creating the new society. * {{flag|United Kingdom}} â On 2 February Prime Minister [[David Cameron]] called for an end to the violence, describing the scenes in Cairo as "despicable" and said they should not be repeated. He said, "We have been watching the events in Cairo with grave concern, and completely condemn the violence that is taking place. And if it turns out that the regime, in any way, has been sponsoring or tolerating this violence, that would be completely and utterly unacceptable. These are despicable scenes that we are seeing and they should not be repeated. They underline the need for political reform and, frankly, for that political reform to be accelerated and to happen quickly. We need to see a clear roadmap for that political reform, so that people in Egypt can have confidence that their aspirations for a more democratic, a future with greater rights, is met. And that change needs to start happening now, and the violence needs to stop."<ref>[[Press release]] (2 February 2011). [http://www.fco.gov.uk/en/news/latest-news/?view=News&id=543555682 "Prime Minister Condemns Violence in Egypt"]. [[Foreign and Commonwealth Office]] ([[United Kingdom]]). Retrieved 2 February 2011.</ref>
